sec.title: Background:
sec.p: The open-access model has changed the landscape of academic publishing over the last 20 years. An unfortunate consequence has been the advent of predatory publishing, which exploits the open-access model for monetary gain by collecting publishing fees from authors under the pretense of being a legitimate publication while providing little-to-no peer review. This study aims to investigate the predatory publishing phenomenon in orthopaedic literature.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: We searched Beall’s List of Predatory Journals and Publishers and another list of predatory journals for journal titles that are possibly related to orthopaedics. We then searched their web sites for the following information: total number of articles published, journal country of origin, author country of origin, article processing charge (APC), quoted review time, and location of the listed headquarters. We also reported the article quality of a random sample of these journals. We consulted InCites Journal Citation Reports to determine the number of nonpredatory orthopaedic publications that are indexed, and we manually searched a random sample of these legitimate journals for Beall’s criteria. Additionally, we searched the Directory of Open Access Journals (DOAJ) and PubMed databases for any possible predatory journal titles.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: We found 104 suspected predatory publishers, representing 225 possible predatory journals. One journal was indexed in the DOAJ, and 20 were indexed in PubMed. Review time was not identified for 56.2% of the journals, and 36.5% quoted a review time of <1 month. Nearly half of the listed addresses of the publishers were either unsearchable or led to residential or empty lots. Eighty-two legitimate journals were identified. The median APC was $420 for predatory journals and $2,900 for legitimate journals. We found that a random sample of the legitimate journals published studies with higher reporting standards, but a few also contained 1 criterion that is found on Beall’s list.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: This study highlights the scope of orthopaedic predatory publishing. Possibly predatory journals outnumber legitimate orthopaedic journals. Orthopaedic surgeons should be aware of the suspected predatory journals and consult available online tools to identify them because distinguishing them from legitimate journals can be a challenge.

body.p: There has been a substantial change in the academic publishing industry with the growth of the Internet. It has allowed for greater volumes of publication and expanded journal distribution1. However, over the last 20 years, the increasing costs have led to the development of the open-access (OA) movement2, which sought to make published literature more accessible and relied on fees from authors and institutions. Predatory journals started to emerge2, and capitalized on the ever-increasing pressure that is placed on researchers to publish3.

The term “predatory journals,” which is defined as journals from counterfeit publishers that exploit the OA model to extract fees from authors, was coined by librarian Jeffrey Beall2-4. The publishers defraud using the OA model by failing to conduct legitimate peer review and lacking editorial transparency while soliciting fees3. In recent years, the growth of predatory journals has been exponential, and they threaten legitimate research1,3,5. Beall curated a database of “potential, possible, or probable predatory scholarly open-access publishers,” which served as the main record for this problem; however, his web site was taken down suddenly and unexpectedly in early 2017. The most up-to-date version of Beall’s list is archived online6.

Journals and publishers are identified as potentially or borderline predatory when they fit specific criteria. Beall’s criteria of >50 qualities of predatory journals were made public after initial criticisms of the list had been made privately7. Other authors also have shared their own criteria8,9. Currently, there is no universally accepted guide; in general, predatory journals are said to have common traits, including promised short review times, an overly broad scope, aggressive e-mail and other forms of author solicitation, little-to-no peer review, editorial boards that are composed of academics without their prior knowledge or with falsified qualifications, journal titles that are similar to other preexisting journals, unprofessionally designed web sites and e-mails with grammatical and spelling errors, falsified or misrepresented contact addresses that are listed as their locations, poor journal practice standards, falsification or lack of listed impact factors, and lack of transparency on authorship or article processing charges (APCs).

According to some recent studies3,5, predatory journals frequently are found in biomedical research and are pervasive in developed countries and in low and middle-income countries9. To our knowledge, no study has fully explored this phenomenon in the orthopaedic literature, although a 2014 study did raise this concern10. The aims of our study were (1) to determine the prevalence of suspected predatory journals within the orthopaedic literature, (2) to identify common characteristics of suspected orthopaedic predatory journals in comparison with indexed legitimate journals, and (3) to determine if these publications are indexed in legitimate databases.

sec.title: Database Search
sec.p: A manual search of an archived version of Beall’s List of Predatory Journals and Publishers6 and another independent list of predatory journals11 (accessed June 2017) was performed independently by 3 of our authors (L.-P.B., J.R.Y., and J.R.L.). Journals and publishers were listed if they fit Beall’s criteria (Table I). Keyword search terms included arthro*, bone, hip, joint, knee, musculoskeletal, ortho*, spine, and sport*. We based our methodology on previously described strategies3,5. Journal titles containing these keywords were retained, and 3 of our authors (H.B., G.S., and J.R.L.) independently pulled data from the web sites. Discrepancies were handled by consensus with a senior author. We manually searched and reviewed the available web sites of the orthopaedic journal titles that were identified on Beall’s list, and compiled a list of criteria for “predatory” or “possibly predatory” journals according to Beall’s criteria.

caption.p: Beall’s Criteria for Screening Possible, Potential, or Probable Predatory or Questionable Journals or Publishers*

tr.td: Editor and staff
• The publisher’s owner is identified as the editor of each and every journal published by the organization.†
• No single individual is identified as any specific journal’s editor.
• The journal does not identify a formal editorial/review board.†
• No academic information is provided regarding the editor, the editorial staff, and/or the review board members.†
• Evidence exists showing that the editor and/or review board members do not possess academic expertise to reasonably qualify them to be publication gatekeepers in the journal’s field.†
• 2 or more journals have duplicate editorial boards (i.e., same editorial board for >1 journal).

• The journals have an insufficient number of board members (e.g., 2 or 3 members), have concocted editorial boards (made up names), name scholars on their editorial board without their knowledge or permission,† or have board members who are prominent researchers but exempt them from any contributions to the journal except the use of their names and/or photographs.
• There is little or no geographical diversity among the editorial board members, especially for journals that claim to be international in scope or coverage.
• The editorial board engages in sex bias (i.e., exclusion of any female members).
Business management
The publisher:
• Demonstrates a lack of transparency in publishing operations.†
• Has no policies or practices for digital preservation.†
• Begins operations with a large fleet of journals, often using a common template to quickly create each journal’s home page.
• Provides insufficient information or hides information about author fees, offering to publish an author’s paper and later sending an unanticipated “surprise” invoice.†
• Does not allow search engines to crawl the published content, preventing the content from being indexed in academic indexes.
• Copy-proofs (locks) their PDFs (Portable Document Formats), thus making it harder to check for plagiarism.†
Integrity
• The name of a journal is incongruent with the journal’s mission.

• The name of a journal does not adequately reflect its origin (e.g., a journal with the word “Canadian” or “Swiss” in its name when neither the publisher, editor, nor any purported institutional affiliate relates whatsoever to Canada or Switzerland).†

• In its spam e-mail or on its web site, the publisher falsely claims 1 or more of its journals have actual (Thomson Reuters) impact factors, or advertises impact factors assigned by fake “impact-factor” services, or it uses some made up measure (e.g., view factor), feigning/claiming an exaggerated international standing.†

• The publisher sends spam requests for peer review to scholars who are unqualified to review submitted manuscripts, in the sense that the specialties of the invited reviewers do not match the papers that are sent to them.†

• The publisher falsely claims to have its content indexed in legitimate abstracting and indexing services or claims that its content is indexed in resources that are not abstracting and indexing services.

• The publisher dedicates insufficient resources to preventing and eliminating author misconduct, to the extent that the journal or journals suffer from repeated cases of plagiarism, self-plagiarism, image manipulation, and the like.†
• The publisher asks the corresponding author for suggested reviewers, and the publisher subsequently uses the suggested reviewers without sufficiently vetting their qualifications or authenticity.
Other
• Republish papers already published in other venues/outlets without providing appropriate credits.†
• Use boastful language claiming to be a “leading publisher” even though the publisher may only be a start-up or a novice organization.†

• Operate in a Western country chiefly for the purpose of functioning as a vanity press for scholars in a developing country (e.g., utilizing a mail-drop address or P.O. Box address in the United States, while actually operating from a developing country).†
• Provide minimal or no copyediting or proofreading of submissions.†
• Publish papers that are not academic at all (e.g., essays by lay people, polemical editorials, or obvious pseudoscience papers).†
• Have a “contact us” page that only includes a web form or an e-mail address, and the publisher hides or does not reveal its location.
Poor journal standards/practice

The following practices are considered to be reflective of poor journal standards, and, while they do not equal predatory criteria, potential authors should give due consideration to these items prior to manuscript submissions:
• The publisher copies “authors’ guidelines” verbatim (or with minor editing) from other publishers.†

• The publisher lists insufficient contact information, including contact information that does not clearly state the headquarters location or misrepresents the headquarters location (e.g., through the use of addresses that are actually mail drops).†
• The publisher publishes journals that are excessively broad (e.g., Journal of Education) in order to attract more articles and gain more revenue from author fees.
• The publisher publishes journals that combine 2 or more fields that are not normally treated together (e.g., International Journal of Business, Humanities and Technology).†

• The publisher charges authors for publishing but requires transfer of copyright and retains copyright on journal content, or the publisher requires the copyright transfer upon submission of the manuscript.
• The publisher has poorly maintained web sites, including dead links, prominent misspellings, and grammatical errors on the web site.†
• The publisher makes unauthorized use of licensed images on their web site, taken from the open Web, without permission or licensing from the copyright owners.†
• The publisher engages in excessive use of spam e-mail to solicit manuscripts or editorial board memberships.†
• The publishers’ officers use e-mail addresses that end in gmail.com, yahoo.com, or some other free e-mail supplier.

• The publisher fails to state licensing policy information on articles or shows lack of understanding of well-known OA journal article licensing standards, or provides contradictory licensing information.†

• The publisher lacks a published article retraction policy or retracts articles without a formal statement (stealth retractions); also, the publisher does not publish corrections or clarifications and does not have a policy for these issues.
• The publisher does not use standard identifiers such as ISSNs or DOIs, or uses them improperly.†

• For the name of the publisher, the publisher uses names such as “Network,” “Center,” “Association,” “Institute,” and the like when it is only a solitary, proprietary operation and does not meet the definition of the term used or the implied nonprofit mission.
• The publisher has excessive, cluttered advertising on its site to the extent that it interferes with site navigation and content access.
• The publisher has no membership in industry associations and/or intentionally fails to follow industry standards.†

• The publisher includes links to legitimate conferences and associations on its main web site, as if to borrow from other organizations’ legitimacy and emblazon the new publisher with the others’ legacy value.
• The publisher displays prominent statements that promise rapid publication and/or unusually quick peer review.
• Evidence exists showing that the publisher does not really conduct a bona fide peer review.†

• The publisher appears to focus exclusively on article processing-fee procurement, while not providing services for readers, or on billing for fees while abdicating any effort at vetting submissions.†

• The publisher creates a publishing operation that demonstrates rapacious entrepreneurial behavior that rises to the level of sheer greed. The individual might have business administration experience, and the site may even have business journals, but the owner seems oblivious to business ethics.†
• The publisher or its journals are not listed in standard periodical directories or are not widely cataloged in library databases.
• The publisher copies or egregiously mimics journal titles from other publishers.†
• The publisher includes text on its web site that describes the open-access movement and then foists the publisher as if the publisher is active in fulfilling the movement’s values and goals.
• None of the members of a particular journal’s editorial board have ever published an article in the journal.

• There is little or no geographic diversity among the authors of articles in 1 or more of the publisher’s journals, an indication that the journal has become an easy outlet for authors from 1 country or region to get scholarly publications.
• The publisher has an optional “fast-track” fee-based service for expedited peer review that appears to provide assured publication with little or no vetting.†

fn.p: Formerly available online at https://scholarlyoa.files.wordpress.com/2015/01/criteria-2015.pdf; cached at https://beallslist.weebly.com.

sec.title: Data Extraction
sec.p: Our study targeted the total number of articles published to date, the average number of articles published annually, the country of origin of the journal, the country of origin of the authors, the APC, and the length of time for manuscript review.

sec.title: Location Verification
sec.p: We used a random number generator (random.org) to select 10% of the collected journals. We searched their online addresses using Google Maps, a web-based mapping service.

sec.title: Cross-Referencing with Standard Indexing
sec.p: We also aimed to verify if any of the retained journals were indexed on the MEDLINE or PubMed databases. Subsequently, we checked the suspected journals against the Directory of Open Access Journals (DOAJ) and PubMed, which were considered to represent white lists to determine if any of the predatory orthopaedic journals were indexed. Finally, the Thomson Reuters InCites Journal Citation Reports were consulted to determine the number of nonpredatory orthopaedic journals. We searched the web sites for a random sample of 26 of these journals (using random.org) to determine if they possessed any of Beall’s criteria.

sec.title: Study Design and Reporting Quality
sec.p: We derived a random set of 30 journals (using random.org) from our original list of suspected journals, and also derived a corresponding random selection from the indexed journals. We manually scanned these journals for published randomized controlled trials and/or meta-analyses. We used the most recently published studies because they represent the most current standard of quality that is accepted for publication by a particular journal. CONSORT (Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials) and PRISMA (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic reviews and Meta-Analyses) checklists were used to evaluate the reporting quality of the published randomized controlled trials and meta-analyses, respectively.

sec.title: Data Analysis
sec.p: Data were entered in Google Sheets (2017), and descriptive statistical analyses were performed.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Beall’s list included 104 possible predatory publishers in the field of orthopaedics (Table II). The 104 publishers produce 225 orthopaedic journals with a total of 10,697 manuscripts. Of the 225 suspected journals, only 1 (0.44%) is indexed in the DOAJ, while 20 (8.9%) are indexed in PubMed (Table III). In contrast to these suspected titles, 82 journals were found in the Thomson Reuters InCites Journal Citation Reports. We searched a random sample of these journals’ web sites to assess the prevalence of Beall’s criteria among legitimate journals, and found 3 examples where 1 criterion was met (Table IV).

sec.p: Additional analysis of the 225 titles that were found with our search of Beall’s list and the other predatory journal list did reveal suspect or possibly predatory traits, including poorly designed web sites with broken links and spelling and/or grammatical errors; addresses that linked to mail drops, residential houses, or known offshore offices; fast-tracked fee-based submission approvals; and editors who were unaware that they were listed as being on the journal’s editorial board. Data were occasionally difficult to collect: 22 journal web sites were unavailable, unstable, lacking content, or unsafe for access. The most common journal addresses were located in the United States (56.4%), followed by India (13.8%) (Fig. 1). Most authors publishing in predatory orthopaedic journals came from India, followed by the United States (Fig. 2). A physical address search with use of Google Maps’ Street View of a sample of approximately 10% of the journal titles (n = 24) found that 7 (29.2%) were nondescript office buildings without a company label (Fig. 3-A); 5 (20.8%) were vague and unsearchable (i.e., “USA,” “New York, USA”), and 6 (25%) resulted in either a residential house or a location without a physical office (Fig. 3 and Table V).

caption.p: Distribution of predatory journals in orthopaedic and musculoskeletal sciences by country of origin.
Distribution of articles published in predatory journals by geographic region. The country was determined based on the location of the first author’s institution.

Figs. 3-A through 3-E Image search of addresses of suspected predatory orthopaedic journals. Fig. 3-A As found on Google Maps’ Street View, a nondescript office building without the name of the publishing company. Fig. 3-B A residential building. Fig. 3-C A publishing company was listed on Google Maps, but no publishing office is seen with Street View. Fig. 3-D No physical building at the address (empty lot or virtual office). Fig. 3-E Academic building (university or hospital). Some addresses were not seen on Street View.

sec.p: We then sampled and searched our list for high-level study designs, and assessed the quality for those that were found. Of the 30 possible predatory journals that were sampled for randomized controlled trials and meta-analyses, only 3 had published randomized controlled trials, and none had published any meta-analyses. The median CONSORT checklist score was 6.5 (range, 4 to 15) of 25. In comparison, the 30 randomly sampled indexed journals contained 6 randomized controlled trials (median CONSORT score, 23.75 of 25; range, 17 to 25) and 20 meta-analyses (median PRISMA score, 26 of 27; range, 19 to 27).

The APCs of these journals varied: 68.6% specified their APCs, while 24% did not mention their APCs (or provided them only on request); 7% of the journals did not have available information (Fig. 4). The median APC for a possible predatory journal was $420 U.S. dollars (USD) (range, $75 to $3,619; interquartile range [IQR], $269 to $1,027); in comparison, the median APC of a legitimate indexed journal was $2,900 USD (range, $0 to $4,754; IQR, $2,114.50 to $3,000). Time to review was listed as <1 month in 36.5% of the predatory orthopaedic journals. However, most journals (56.2%) either failed to mention the review time, had a dysfunctional web site, or had a discrepancy between the journal and the publisher regarding the review time (Fig. 5).

caption.p: APC information availability for potential authors, as made available on the journals’ web sites. “Unable to determine” represented an inaccessible or dysfunctional web site or an inactive journal.
Maximum time to review a submitted article as advertised by the possible predatory journals.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Our investigation identified 104 suspicious publishers representing 225 possible or potential predatory orthopaedic journals. This is nearly 3 times greater than the number of indexed journals (n = 82) found in the Thomson Reuters InCites Journal Citation Reports portal. These results matched patterns discovered by investigators in other fields3,5,12. The 1 journal that was indexed by the DOAJ was further investigated. Its web site did not offer a secure connection, which raised a question regarding the security of author data. Another issue is that the journal advertises that there is “no article processing charge,” but also offers an author portal tool for fee and invoice requests, which was confusing at the very least. The final, and most suspicious, point was noted by our senior author, who discovered that a colleague was listed on the board of editors but was unaware of being involved with that particular journal and actually had no role with it. The DOAJ has recently implemented stricter inclusion requirements for indexing journals after hundreds of questionable journals on Beall’s list were found on its database13. Its current vetting criteria now include >50 requirements7,14. PubMed and MEDLINE’s vetting process is led by the Literature Selection Technical Review Committee, a federal advisory committee, which evaluates a journal’s quality of editorial work, review process, ethical guidelines, disclosure of financial conflicts of interests, and conformance to other scholarly publishing best-practices guidelines15. However, it has been attested that PubMed’s process can be circumvented: after submitting publications to PubMed Central, a publisher obtains an identifying number and then becomes listed in the database. This has raised concern for more rigorous screening criteria16.

Twenty possible predatory journal titles were found indexed on PubMed. For each title, a manual search through that journal’s web site as well as a general online search of the journal’s and publisher’s name were conducted (Table III). Each of these journals had concerning characteristics or belonged to publishers with suspicious findings. The most common qualities that were found were inaccurate or vague address locations, a history of excessive spam e-mails, poor-quality web sites with broken links, unsecure pages, or multiple grammatical and/or spelling errors; in addition, they offered express or premium services for additional fees. Several of the journals were found to be part of publishing companies that had been caught printing hoax papers during investigative sting operations.

Searching through the random sample of indexed legitimate journals, we found 3 whose web sites had information that fit Beall’s criteria (Table IV). One journal was flagged because of “little or no geographic diversity among the editorial” board; however, on further investigation, we found that the title indicates an official national journal, which would mean its editorial scope would have a tight national focus7. Two were flagged for having only listed 1 editor on its board, which fits Beall’s criteria of having an “insufficient number” of editors7. However, additional examination of the articles found that many guest editors were listed along with the single consulting editor. Even though these criteria were noted, we did not find any other traces of predatory or suspicious practices in these journals; therefore, these criteria, in isolation, should not be condemning. However, this does highlight the risk that these criteria represent for inadvertently mislabeling a journal as predatory.

The APC was mentioned for 68.6% of the suspected journals, with a median of $420 USD (IQR, $269 to $1,027). This is less than the median for the legitimate journals ($2,900 USD) and the industry average: previous research has demonstrated costs of $4,871 for print and online access only, $3,509 for subscription online only, and $2,289 for OA online only17. Two studies by Manca et al. had similar findings: predatory rehabilitation journals had average APCs of $751 compared with $1,103 for nonpredatory journals, and predatory neuroscience journals had APCs that ranged from $521 to $637 compared with $1,000 for nonpredatory journals3,5. Shamseer et al. found predatory journals charging median APCs ($100) that were lower than those of nonpredatory journals ($1,866)8. Lower APCs are thought to lure more potential researchers, which provides greater revenue for the journals11,18.

The advertised time to review also was analyzed and was listed to be <1 month for 36.5% of the predatory orthopaedic journals. The majority (56.2%) did not specify review time. The median time to review for those that did specify it was 3 weeks (IQR, 2 to 4 weeks), which is lower than the industry average of approximately 14.3 weeks19. Some journals advertised peer review within days from when a manuscript is submitted. In our investigation, we found journals that advertised a review time as low as 7 days.

The most prevalent countries of origin for the predatory journals were India, the United States, and the U.K. (Fig. 1). However, many of the predatory journals listed >1 office location: often, the first office that is listed is located in a high-income country, and a second location is in a less-developed nation, perhaps to be more appealing to potential authors. Most authors were from India, the United States, the U.K., and Japan (Fig. 2). There may be an increased pressure for scholars in those countries to publish because academic publishing is linked to financial incentives or may be required for career advancement20-23. This drive has led to increased submissions, which begets more rejections20,21,24. This pressure has been identified as a factor for research misconduct25-27, and may contribute to the creation of a market for lesser-quality journals, some of which may be predatory, with less-stringent review processes for printing articles28,29. Using a random sample of predatory journals and indexed legitimate journals, our study found that fewer randomized controlled trials and no meta-analyses were published in the predatory sample. The CONSORT scores were lower for the randomized controlled trials found in the predatory journal sample than for any of the randomized controlled trials found among the indexed journals (median score of 6.5 versus 23.75 of 25, respectively).

Investigating the listed locations of a randomly selected sample of suspected predatory journals revealed that there are questionable office addresses. Many of the locations were empty, were residential homes, or were unsearchable. This is consistent with other studies that demonstrate that listing false addresses or not listing a physical address are unethical business practices of predatory journals3,4. One study reported a rate of nearly 25% for addresses that were vague or impossible to determine4, compared with our rate of 20.8%.

Reports show that predatory journals have failed to meet the international standards for publication, and there are many red flags, including poor peer-review processes, fake editors, plagiarism, articles that may have questionable results that are unable to be verified accurately or be reproduced, ethical misconduct, and unclear methodology30,31. On other occasions, papers have been published in predatory journals describing experiments that have not been conducted, and authorship of prewritten papers has been sold28,29. The damage of such actions to the scientific process and the community is serious and could potentially adversely affect the quality of orthopaedic research.

sec.title: Study Limitations
sec.p: The limitations of this paper are tied to the sources of data that we searched. Our data came from the last version of Beall’s list in early 2017 (before the web site was taken down) and another anonymous web site that had been inspired by Beall’s work. Beall’s list, although well-known and extensive, was not validated before its deletion, and was initially criticized for lack of transparency on how it applied its criteria and for being unavailable for reproducibility. There was concern that there may have been unfair listings of legitimate journals32. Some of the criteria can be broadly overapplied, and therefore are not specifically limited to just predatory journals (Table IV). Recently, another company developed a blacklist of untrusted journals, but there is limited accessibility to this list because of its industry-level pricing32. Given the competing risks of missing questionable journals and of mislabeling legitimate journals as predatory, future research should design and validate tools and criteria.

sec.title: Future Directions and Recommendations
sec.p: The scientific community needs to increase awareness of how to identify and avoid predatory journals. This is especially important for junior researchers because 65% of their publications are by first-time authors17; many have recounted being lured by the promise of quick publication, only to regret it after being hounded for additional publication fees33. The poor publication practices of predatory journals also could affect clinical care10,32,34. Criteria previously identified to reveal possible predatory journals8,9,35 include low APCs; spelling and grammatical errors on web sites; an overly broad scope; language that targets authors rather than readers; promises of rapid publication (for additional fees); and a lack of information about retraction policies, copyright, manuscript handling, or digital preservation. Our study found that suspected predatory orthopaedic journals share these characteristics; they also named unaware physicians as serving on editorial boards and listed illegitimate headquarter addresses.

We recommend that research and funding organizations track possible predatory orthopaedic journals to further limit the spread of these journals. Use of the “think-check-submit” strategy when searching for a journal to publish one’s work is encouraged36. Other tips include checking the journal title against the DOAJ (which serves as a white list), ensuring that the editorial board includes recognizable and trustworthy researchers, and evaluating the journal for any of the aforementioned predatory traits. Finally, novel journal evaluation tools that help to assess for possible predatory journals are being developed, although validation is ongoing37. Current and future orthopaedic physicians and academics need to be aware of the phenomenon of predatory publishing and take active measures to limit its spread.
